message: I'm guessing it was a .js based issue?
https://grepular.com/Case_Study_Multiple_Convore_Security_Privacy_Problems
Does that mean that you are not using this decorator ?
Too easy to set up a fake version of the login page and start harvesting passwords.
My question is in fact : is this security problem present on all django sites ?
https://convore.com/login/?next=https://grepular.com/
Very interesting read. I have a question about the security problem using the redirect after login  :

@madewulf I'm not sure, I'm not using Django's decorator.  I think it's possible it's a vulnerability.  In this case I think it's one of those things where reasonable people disagree on what's a feature and what's a vulnerability.
I have a bad case of NIH
(But you guys fixed that, at least according to the grepular page.)
But I don't claim to be a security expert, so I'm not sure.
Django's login_required is not vulnerable because it calls urlparse.urlparse on the redirect_to, and refuses to use it if its a redirect to a different host.
In my first test, it does not work with django login_required.
Thanks, @madewulf :)
@madewulf Yeah?
(And urlparse handles scheme-relative URLs correctly).
A login-redirect that's vulnerable to remote redirection is not in that category, IMO.
It does not seem to happen on my django sites, with the login_required decorator
@carljm Yeah, some of that stuff I didn't fix
@carljm Yeah, we definitely did.
Which is a good news ;-)
Nice site btw.
Then it's probably a lesson in avoiding NIH :)
@ericflo I would say some of the stuff about detecting if a user is logged in to convore is "reasonable people could disagree."
Nice that all this was caught early.  You guys got a free security audit. :)
